abstract.p: Susan Jo Keller reviews Ellen Wright's new cookbook, Bridgehampton Weekends, Easy Menus for Casual Entertaining; photo (M)

Ellen Wright is far from an old-timer. She didn't spend her first summer in the Hamptons until 1971.
But it didn't take long for her to conclude that it was the place she wanted to call home, a home for all seasons.

She's written a love letter, of sorts, to the place where shore and sky meet, in a new cookbook ''Bridgehampton Weekends, Easy Menus for Casual Entertaining,'' which is being published next month by William McMorrow.

The book, illustrated with photographs by Tom Ecklerle, starts where summer ends for many people: on Labor Day, for a dinner for four that features pan-grilled veal chops, a puree of lima beans and peas. Another fall offering, sesame short ribs with tortillas, makes me yearn for a cool day even before I have been sated with summer sunshine. Which is not to say that the summer menus don't sound enticing, with their lavish use of the season's freshest fruits and vegetables.

These are not recipes designed to show off ingredients that are showing up for their brief 15 minutes of fame. A handful of fresh cilantro leaves is just about as exotic as it gets. Ms. Wright, a long-time assistant to James Beard, has written a book for cooks, hosts and hostesses who want to get back to the basics of entertaining: good food and good friends.
